references:
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows.
Section 2 first introduces the background of this paper.
Then we propose BLADE-FL in Section 3, and optimize the upper bound on the loss function in Section 4.
Section 5 investigates the issue of lazy clients.
Section 6 discusses the privacy issue.
The experimental results are presented in Section 7.
Section 8 concludes this paper.
In addition, Table I lists the main notations used in this paper.

references:
Fig. 4 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of α𝛼\alpha (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while Table II shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. Here, we set β=6𝛽6\beta=6. First, Fig. 4(a) shows that larger α𝛼\alpha leads to larger loss function. This is due to the fact that both K𝐾K and τ𝜏\tau from (3) drops as α𝛼\alpha grows.
Second, from Table II, the longer a training iteration consumes, the more training time each client takes. For example, using MNIST, the training time increases from 404040 to 646464 as α𝛼\alpha rises from 111 to 555. This observation is consistent with Corollary 1.

β=6𝛽6\beta=6 60 30 87.47% 61.51%

Fig. 5 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of β𝛽\beta (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while Table III shows the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.
First, Fig. 5(a) shows that larger β𝛽\beta leads to larger loss function, since both K𝐾K and τ𝜏\tau from (3) drops as β𝛽\beta grows.
Second, from Table III, K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} reduces as β𝛽\beta rises, but the optimal mining time β​K∗𝛽superscript𝐾\beta K^{*} goes up as β𝛽\beta rises. For example, using MNIST, the mining time increases from 606060 to 727272 as β𝛽\beta grows from 666 to 121212. This observation agrees with Corollary 1.

references:
Fig. 6 shows the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of N𝑁N, while Table IV illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.
We set β=6𝛽6\beta=6. First, from Table IV, we notice that the optimal mining time drops as N𝑁N increases, which is consistent with Proposition 3. For example, using MNIST, β​K∗𝛽superscript𝐾\beta K^{*} drops from 707070 to 505050 as N𝑁N rises from 101010 to 252525.
Second, from Fig. 6(a), larger N𝑁N leads to lower loss function. This is because the involved datasets are larger as N𝑁N grows, which causes a smaller loss function. Third, from both Fig. 6(a) and (b), K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} approaches a fixed value when N𝑁N is sufficiently large (e.g., N>20𝑁20N>20). This observation is in line with Corollary 3.

η=0.005𝜂0.005\eta=0.005 54 30 74.70% 58.57%

references:
Fig. 7 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of η𝜂\eta, while Table V illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy.
First, from Table V, we find that the optimal mining time rises as η𝜂\eta grows, which is in line with Corollary 4. For example, using MNIST, β​K∗𝛽superscript𝐾\beta K^{*} rises from 545454 to 727272 as η𝜂\eta grows from 0.0050.0050.005 to 0.10.10.1. Second, from Fig. 7(a), the loss function drops as η𝜂\eta increases except η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1. This is because η𝜂\eta grows significantly when η​L<1𝜂𝐿1\eta L<1, and our developed upper bound is no longer suitable. For example, when η>0.05𝜂0.05\eta>0.05, the loss function increases as η𝜂\eta rises in our experiments for both MNIST and Fashion-MNIST.

Fig. 8 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of lazy ratio MN𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{N}, while Table VI shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. We set the power of artificial noise σ2=0.01superscript𝜎20.01\sigma^{2}=0.01.
First, from Table VI, it is observed the optimal training time steps up as MN𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{N} increases. For example, using MNIST, the time allocated to training rises from 303030 to 505050 as MN𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{N} increases from 0%percent00\% to 30%percent3030\%. This observation is consistent with Corollary 5.
Second, from Fig. 8(a), the learning performance degrades as MN𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{N} grows. This is because more lazy clients involved in the system as MN𝑀𝑁\frac{M}{N} grows, leading to lower training efficiency.

Fig. 9 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, while Table VII shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. We set MN=20%𝑀𝑁percent20\frac{M}{N}=20\%.
First, from Table VII, we notice that the optimal training time τ​α​K∗𝜏𝛼superscript𝐾\tau\alpha K^{*} grows as σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} increases, which agrees with Corollary 5. For example, using MNIST, τ​α​K∗𝜏𝛼superscript𝐾\tau\alpha K^{*} grows from 303030 to 505050 as σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} increases from 0.010.010.01 to 0.30.30.3.
Second, from Fig. 9(a), the learning performance of BLADE-FL (i.e., loss function and accuracy) degrades as the noise power σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} goes larger.
